questions.question: The man seemed [haggard] after the day's hard work.
questions.explanation: The antonym of haggard (looking exhausted and unwell, especially from fatigue) is fresh (having just arrived or been done; clean and energetic).

questions.question: The news reporter was quite [laconic] in his reportage of the event.
questions.explanation: The antonym of laconic (using very few words) is elaborate (developed or presented in detail).

questions.question: The man was asked to [ameliorate] the condition of the people.
questions.explanation: The antonym of ameliorate (to make something bad or unsatisfactory better) is worsen (to make or become worse).

questions.question: His [parsimonious] attitude to work made him unpopular with his subordinates.
questions.explanation: The antonym of parsimonious (extremely unwilling to spend money or use resources) is generous (showing a readiness to give more than is necessary).

questions.question: The doctor says the injury is only [superficial].
questions.explanation: The antonym of superficial (existing or occurring at or on the surface) is deep (extending a long way down or in from the top or surface).

questions.question: The crowd at the stadium was [vociferous].
questions.explanation: The antonym of vociferous (crying out or protesting loudly) is silent (not making or accompanied by any sound).

questions.question: His wife is always [morose] at home.
questions.explanation: The antonym of morose (sullen and ill-tempered) is happy (feeling or showing pleasure or contentment).

questions.question: The country has not experienced such [turbulent] times in the past.
questions.explanation: The antonym of turbulent (characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion; not controlled or calm) is calm (not troubled or agitated).

questions.question: Tolu's attitude to life is quite [pessimistic].
questions.explanation: The antonym of pessimistic (tending to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen) is optimistic (hopeful and confident about the future).

questions.question: The governor was very [obsequious] to the president.
questions.explanation: The antonym of obsequious (obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree) is rude (impolite or uncivil).

questions.question: The politician was [impeached] for his corrupt practices.
questions.explanation: The antonym of impeached (charged with misconduct) is pardoned (forgiven for an error or offense).

questions.question: The lady was [fastidious] about the way she dressed.
questions.explanation: The antonym of fastidious (very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail; meticulous) is careless (not giving sufficient attention or thought to avoiding harm or error).

questions.question: The [gargantuan] monster swallowed the little boat.
questions.explanation: The antonym of gargantuan (enormous) is tiny (extremely small).

questions.question: The king's actions showed [pusillanimity].
questions.explanation: The antonym of pusillanimity (lack of courage or determination; cowardice) is bravery (courageous behavior or character).

questions.question: There was a [paucity] of ideas in the essay.
questions.explanation: The antonym of paucity (the presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities or amounts; scarcity) is excess (an amount of something that is more than necessary, permitted, or desirable).

questions.question: He was quite [unctuous] in his remark.
questions.explanation: The antonym of unctuous (excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; insincere) is sincere (free from pretense or deceit; honest).

questions.question: His [jocund] mood was quite infectious.
questions.explanation: The antonym of jocund (cheerful and lighthearted) is sad (feeling or showing sorrow; unhappy).

questions.question: The story the witness told was quite [incredulous].
questions.explanation: The antonym of incredulous (unwilling or unable to believe something) is credible (able to be believed; plausible).

questions.question: The new governor's regime was characterized by [profligate] spending.
questions.explanation: The antonym of profligate (recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources) is frugal (sparing or economical with regard to money or food).

questions.question: His words were very [euphonious].
questions.explanation: The antonym of euphonious (pleasing to the ear) is harsh (unpleasantly rough or jarring to the senses).

questions.question: His reaction to the proposal was quite [derogatory].
questions.explanation: The antonym of derogatory (showing a critical or disrespectful attitude; insulting) is complimentary (expressing a compliment or praise).

questions.question: She's a [sanguine] person who never worries.
questions.explanation: The antonym of sanguine (optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation) is gloomy (sad or depressing).

questions.question: He was advised to adopt a [prudent] approach to the issue.
questions.explanation: The antonym of prudent (acting with or showing care and thought for the future) is reckless (without thinking or caring about the consequences of an action).

questions.question: The [ubiquitous] nature of the problem made it difficult to resolve.
questions.explanation: The antonym of ubiquitous (present, appearing, or found everywhere) is rare (not occurring very often).

questions.question: She's always [loquacious] in class.
questions.explanation: The antonym of loquacious (tending to talk a great deal; verbose) is quiet (making little or no noise).

questions.question: The speaker's style of presentation was [incoherent].
questions.explanation: The antonym of incoherent (expressed in an incomprehensible or confusing way) is intelligible (able to be understood; comprehensible).

questions.question: The workers felt the company's decision was [draconian].
questions.explanation: The antonym of draconian (excessively harsh and severe) is lenient (permissive, merciful, or tolerant).

questions.question: The man was [ostentatious] in his dress.
questions.explanation: The antonym of ostentatious (characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress) is modest (unassuming in the estimation of one's abilities or achievements).

questions.question: It is not [expedient] to rely solely on one method.
questions.explanation: The antonym of expedient (convenient and practical, although possibly improper or immoral) is disadvantageous (involving or creating adverse circumstances).

questions.question: The audience was disappointed with the speaker's rather [insipid] lecture.
questions.explanation: The antonym of insipid (lacking vigor or interest; dull) is lively (full of life and energy).

questions.question: The two politicians have always been [inimical] to each other.
questions.explanation: The antonym of inimical (tending to obstruct or harm; hostile) is friendly (kind and pleasant).

questions.question: The problem has become [intractable] over the years.
questions.explanation: The antonym of intractable (hard to control or deal with) is manageable (able to be controlled or dealt with).

questions.question: We had to wait for the [culmination] of the show before leaving.
questions.explanation: The antonym of culmination (the highest point of achievement; the end) is beginning (the point in time or space at which something starts).

questions.question: The matter was handled with [aplomb].
questions.explanation: The antonym of aplomb (complete assurance or self-confidence) is confusion (lack of clarity or order).

questions.question: Many diseases are becoming [resistant] to antibiotics.
questions.explanation: The antonym of resistant (offering resistance to something or someone) is vulnerable (exposed to the possibility of being attacked or harmed).

questions.question: The committee's decision was generally [acceptable].
questions.explanation: The antonym of acceptable (able to be endured or allowed; satisfactory) is unsuitable (not appropriate for a particular purpose or occasion).

questions.question: The man's life was [abject] from the beginning.
questions.explanation: The antonym of abject (extremely bad, unpleasant, and degrading) is honourable (bringing or worthy of honor).

questions.question: The politician was notorious for his [mendacity].
questions.explanation: The antonym of mendacity (untruthfulness) is honesty (the quality of being honest).

questions.question: The country has made [perfunctory] attempts to resolve the crisis.
questions.explanation: The antonym of perfunctory (carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection) is thorough (performed or written with great care and completeness).

questions.question: The general was [recalcitrant] in his views.
questions.explanation: The antonym of recalcitrant (having an obstinately uncooperative attitude) is obedient (complying or willing to comply with an order or request).

questions.question: He was quite [slovenly] in appearance.
questions.explanation: The antonym of slovenly (messy and dirty) is neat (organized, tidy, and clean).

questions.question: He was [gregarious] in his youth.
questions.explanation: The antonym of gregarious (fond of company; sociable) is isolated (far away from other places, buildings, or people; solitary).

questions.question: His [fortitude] in the face of death amazed everyone.
questions.explanation: The antonym of fortitude (courage in pain or adversity) is cowardice (lack of courage).

questions.question: The man was [indolent] in his work.
questions.explanation: The antonym of indolent (avoiding activity or exertion; lazy) is diligent (having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work).

questions.question: The man was accused of [obfuscating] the issues.
questions.explanation: The antonym of obfuscating (making something obscure, unclear, or unintelligible) is clarifying (making something clearer and more comprehensible).

questions.question: There was [enmity] between the two clans.
questions.explanation: The antonym of enmity (the state or feeling of being actively opposed or hostile to someone or something) is friendship (the state of being friends).

questions.question: His wife's [volubility] has made her the envy of her friends.
questions.explanation: The antonym of volubility (the quality of talking fluently, readily, or incessantly) is silence (complete absence of sound or speech).

questions.question: The politician was well known for his [duplicity].
questions.explanation: The antonym of duplicity (deceitfulness; double-dealing) is honesty (the quality of being honest).

questions.question: The [frivolous] attitude of the principal to the issue surprised everyone.
questions.explanation: The antonym of frivolous (not having any serious purpose or value) is serious (acting or speaking sincerely and in earnest).

questions.question: His [candid] approach to the issue helped to resolve the crisis.
questions.explanation: The antonym of candid (truthful and straightforward) is dishonest (behaving or prone to behaving in an untrustworthy or fraudulent way).

questions.question: My eldest brother is now faced with the [vicissitudes] of married life.
questions.explanation: The antonym of vicissitudes (changes of circumstances or fortune, typically unwelcome; ups and downs) is stability (the state of being firmly fixed and unlikely to change).

questions.question: The dancing troupe put up a [flawless] performance.
questions.explanation: The antonym of flawless (without any imperfections; perfect) is imperfect (having faults or shortcomings).

questions.question: The officer said that he knew nothing to the [detriment] of the applicant.
questions.explanation: The antonym of detriment (the state of being harmed or damaged) is advantage (a condition or circumstance that puts one in a favorable position).

questions.question: Common sense requires that one should be [decorous] at formal gatherings.
questions.explanation: The antonym of decorous (in keeping with good taste and propriety; polite) is impolite (not having or showing good manners).

questions.question: The string was [taut],
questions.explanation: The antonym of taut (stretched or pulled tight) is loose (not firmly or tightly fixed in place).

questions.question: The diminutive figure bounces over the track with [unfathomable] lightness.
questions.explanation: The antonym of unfathomable (incapable of being fully understood; mysterious) is predictable (able to be accurately foretold or understood).

questions.question: The teacher announced that the class would be making a [fleeting] visit to the zoo.
questions.explanation: The antonym of fleeting (lasting for a very short time; brief) is long (lasting for a great duration).

questions.question: We intend to make the reception a [diurnal] event.
questions.explanation: The antonym of diurnal (of or during the day; daily) is nightly (of or occurring in the night).

questions.question: The project is designed to [alleviate] poverty in the country.
questions.explanation: The antonym of alleviate (to make suffering or a problem less severe) is exacerbate (to make a problem worse).

questions.question: It is surprising that this politician has now turned [renegade].
questions.explanation: The antonym of renegade (a person who deserts and betrays an organization or principle) is loyal (giving or showing firm and constant support).

questions.question: Hypertension is a [debilitating] disease that everyone should prevent.
questions.explanation: The antonym of debilitating (causing one to feel drained of energy; weakening) is energizing (giving vitality and enthusiasm to).

questions.question: The striking workers have vowed not to return to work until the decision is [rescinded].
questions.explanation: The antonym of rescinded (revoked, cancelled, or repealed) is implemented (put into effect).

questions.question: I'm not interested in buying that shirt. I think it is [overpriced].
questions.explanation: The antonym of overpriced (costing too much) is cheap (low in price).

questions.question: Civil engineering is [predominantly] a male profession.
questions.explanation: The antonym of predominantly (mainly; generally) is seldom (rarely; infrequently).

questions.question: As these boys never act in public, the police are now worried about their [covert] activities.
questions.explanation: The antonym of covert (not openly acknowledged or displayed; secret) is open (accessible or visible; public).

questions.question: Some equatorial areas have a [sultry] climate.
questions.explanation: The antonym of sultry (hot and humid) is temperate (characterized by mild temperatures).

questions.question: Updating the Board's brochure is an [arduous] task.
questions.explanation: The antonym of arduous (involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult) is easy (achieved without great effort).

questions.question: What a [harmless] thought he has!
questions.explanation: The antonym of harmless (not causing harm) is pernicious (having a harmful effect).

questions.question: In his [naivety], he believed all the stories his friend told him.
questions.explanation: The antonym of naivety (lack of experience, wisdom, or judgment) is incredulity (the state of being unwilling or unable to believe something).

questions.question: It is [inconceivable] that the rat devoured the cat.
questions.explanation: The antonym of inconceivable (not capable of being imagined or believed) is credible (able to be believed; plausible).

questions.question: Ali wondered why the principal was [ambivalent] about the students' future.
questions.explanation: The antonym of ambivalent (having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas; uncertain) is decisive (settling an issue; producing a definite result).

questions.question: The teacher taught the [rudiments] of Chemistry to the first grade.
questions.explanation: The antonym of rudiments (the first principles of a subject; basics) is theory (a set of principles on which the practice of an activity is based, often implying advanced knowledge).

questions.question: The journalist's write-up contained a [plethora] of detail
questions.explanation: The antonym of plethora (a large or excessive amount of something; overabundance) is shortage (a lack of sufficient amounts).

questions.question: The town was all [agog] at his unexpected return
questions.explanation: The antonym of agog (highly excited; full of anticipation) is unexcited (not excited; indifferent).

questions.question: The lecture seemed [interminable].
questions.explanation: The antonym of interminable (endless or apparently endless; unending) is brief (of short duration).

questions.question: In the latter part of his life, the famous soldier showed signs of [youthfulness]
questions.explanation: The antonym of youthfulness (the state of being young or vigorous) is senility (the state of being old, often involving mental deterioration).

questions.question: There is much [apathy] towards reading among students nowadays.
questions.explanation: The antonym of apathy (lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern; indifference) is enthusiasm (intense and eager enjoyment or interest).

questions.question: The witness [averred] that she had seen Dosun at the scene of the crime.
questions.explanation: The antonym of averred (stated or asserted to be the case; affirmed) is denied (stated that one refuses to admit the truth or existence of).

questions.question: The high cost of living these days calls for a lot of [frugality].
questions.explanation: The antonym of frugality (the quality of being economical with money; prudence) is extravagance (lack of restraint in spending money or using resources).

questions.question: Tunde's reaction [underscores] the point I was making.
questions.explanation: The antonym of underscores (emphasizes or confirms) is contradicts (denies the truth of a statement, especially by asserting the opposite).

questions.question: Everyone admired the manager's [adroit] handling of the crises in the company.
questions.explanation: The antonym of adroit (clever or skillful in using hands or mind) is clumsy (awkward in movement or handling things).

questions.question: The principal took exception to the [ignoble] role the teacher played in the matter.
questions.explanation: The antonym of ignoble (dishonourable; not aiming at high standards) is honourable (worthy of respect; morally upright).

questions.question: He is [notorious] for his drunkenness.
questions.explanation: The antonym of notorious (famous for some bad quality or deed) is renowned (famous for good qualities).

questions.question: The chairman's conduct [redounds] to the image of the company.
questions.explanation: The antonym of redounds to (contributes to, promotes, or results in a benefit) is detracts from (reduces or takes away from the merit or value of).

questions.question: Her [phlegmatic] temperament endears her to her friends.
questions.explanation: The antonym of phlegmatic (having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition; cold) is irritable (easily annoyed or angered).

questions.question: The workers suddenly became [restive].
questions.explanation: The antonym of restive (unable to keep still or silent, typically because of impatience) is calm (not feeling or showing excitement, anger, or nervousness).

questions.question: The Governor's visit is an [unprecedented] event in the history of the social dub.
questions.explanation: The antonym of unprecedented (never done or known before; momentous) is insignificant (too unimportant to be worth consideration).

questions.question: The athlete has unexpectedly become [indomitable].
questions.explanation: The antonym of indomitable (impossible to defeat; unconquerable) is weak (lacking power or strength).

questions.question: The evidence the leader gave was [incontrovertible]
questions.explanation: The antonym of incontrovertible (not able to be denied or disputed; indubitable) is contestable (able to be disputed or argued).

questions.question: The [hardline] posture of the labour leader has not helped matters.
questions.explanation: The antonym of hardline (a strict, uncompromising position) is compromising (a willingness to accept standards that are lower than desirable; yielding).

questions.question: The President gave another [extemporaneous] speech last Friday.
questions.explanation: The antonym of extemporaneous (spoken or done without preparation; unprepared) is planned (thought out or prepared in advance).

questions.question: Only those who are [gullible] fall victim to his trickery.
questions.explanation: The antonym of gullible (easily persuaded to believe something; naive) is astute (having or showing an ability to accurately assess situations; shrewd).

questions.question: He is well known for his [inordinate] ambition.
questions.explanation: The antonym of inordinate (unusually or disproportionately large; excessive) is moderate (average in amount, intensity, or quality).

questions.question: Students could be [timid].
questions.explanation: The antonym of timid (showing a lack of courage or confidence; easily frightened) is bold (showing a willingness to take risks; confident).

questions.question: The witness decided to [conceal] the evidence.
questions.explanation: The antonym of conceal (to keep secret; hide) is divulge (to make known a secret or private information).

questions.question: The members of the congregation were [inspired] by the sermon.
questions.explanation: The antonym of inspired (filled with the urge or ability to do something creative; motivated) is disenchanted (disappointed by someone or something previously respected).

questions.question: Agbenu was [ecstatic] about her result.
questions.explanation: The antonym of ecstatic (feeling or expressing overwhelming happiness or joyful excitement) is sad (feeling or showing sorrow; unhappy).

questions.question: The labour leader's [recalcitrant] stance was applauded.
questions.explanation: The antonym of recalcitrant (having an obstinately uncooperative attitude; stubbornly resistant) is feeble (lacking physical or mental strength).

questions.question: A cool bath in a hot weather can be truly [invigorating].
questions.explanation: The antonym of invigorating (making one feel full of energy) is debilitating (tending to make one weak or feeble).

questions.question: I am [loath] to do the assignment.
questions.explanation: The antonym of loath (reluctant; unwilling) is willing (ready, eager, or prepared to do something).
